intro: Carex melanantha var. genuina, commonly known as the black sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, grasses, and rushes. This species is characterized by its dark green, cylindrical leaves and produces small, clustered brown flowers in late summer. It typically grows in moist to wet environments such as marshes, bogs, and along stream banks. The plant is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for various wildlife species.
